content.text: The 20th century saw an explosion of new developments in logic. **Model theory** (Tarski), **proof theory** (Gentzen), **computability theory** (Turing), and Gödel's incompleteness theorems transformed the field.

**Alfred Tarski** (1901-1983) created modern model theory and gave the first rigorous definition of truth. His work made precise what it means for a sentence to be 'true in a structure' — the foundation of semantics.

content.definition: The study of the relationship between formal languages and their interpretations (models). It asks: which structures satisfy which sentences?

content.text: **Gerhard Gentzen** (1909-1945) invented natural deduction and sequent calculus, showing how to analyze the structure of proofs themselves. His work founded modern proof theory.

**Alan Turing** (1912-1954) defined computability using 'Turing machines' and proved that some problems are undecidable — no algorithm can solve them. Logic and computer science became deeply intertwined.

content.title: Key 20th Century Results
premises: 1931: Gödel's incompleteness theorems (limits of formal systems)
content.note: These results in a single decade reshaped our understanding of logic, mathematics, and computation.

content.text: Today logic thrives in many areas: mathematical logic, philosophical logic, computer science, linguistics, and artificial intelligence. The ancient Greek invention continues to evolve.

content.question: What did Tarski contribute to logic?
options: A rigorous definition of truth and model theory
content.explanation: Tarski gave the first rigorous definition of truth for formal languages and founded model theory — the study of how sentences relate to the structures that make them true.
